The ossuary is a 1st century chalk box that some believe hold the bones of Jesus' brother. Jennifer Pagonis, 29, has Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome (AIS), a very rare disorder which prevents a womb from growing. The condition causes testes to grow in the abdomen or other unusual places in the body. Pagonis didn't learn the full truth about her condition until a college instructor described the hormone syndrome one day during class. She phoned her mother to discuss her fears and was shocked to find her worst fears confirmed.

Researchers from Okinawa Institute of Science and Technology Graduate University in Japan have found a similar pattern in the distribution of skin cells. They compared the number of 'neighbours' adjacent to fairy circles and skin cells. The majority of skin cells and fairy circles both had six 'neighbours', and similar percentages of other neighbours. The patterns may be similar because both skin cells and fairy circles are fighting for space.

Chilesaurus diegosuarezi was found at the Toqui Formation in southern Chile. It has a small skull and feet, which are more like those seen on long-neck dinosaurs. The animal is proving to be an evolutionary jigsaw puzzle because it belongs to the theropod group of dinosaurs - which includes Velociraptor, Carnotaurus and Tyrannosaurus. It was a vegetarian, despite belonging to the theopod family of dinosaurs, which were mostly fierce meat eaters.

First people to cash in their pots began to receive their money yesterday.

The Nanoheat Wireless Heated Mug is fitted with a rchargeable battery, nanoheater and heat sleeve. It can maintain the temperature of hot drinks at between 68°C and 71°C (155 and 160°F) for up to 45 minutes. The Goldilocks principle is a scientific term for when the state of something falls within certain margins. The mug weighs a little over one pound (454g) and can be charged wirelessly or using a traditional USB cord.

The fossil of Yi qi was discovered by a farmer working his fields in Mutoudeng, in Qinglong County, Hebei Province in China. It had small stiff feathers on its body and long finger-like bones extending from each wrist that were covered in a membrane. Scientists believe the dinosaur, which they have named Yi qi, meaning ‘strange wing’, may have glided or even flown through the air. Discovery has provided new insight into how vertebrates first began to take to the air.

Google launched the new service today, two months after it announced plans to expand its wireless network. The basic phone service will cost $20 a month and will only charge customers for the amount of cellular data that they use each month. Each gigabyte of data will cost $10 a month. Customers can sign up for a plan offering three gigabytes of data and get $20 back if only one gigabyte was used in a month. Google is leasing space on cellular towers built by Sprint and T-Mobile, which are hoping the deals will boost their profits.

Research led by the University of Montana has found that eating fast food after a workout may be just as beneficial as dietary supplements. Researchers found that during recovery periods between periods of exercise, it didn’t matter what food was eaten. Performance remained the same after resting for several hours. Levels of glycogen - used by muscles as ‘fuel’ - were actually slightly higher after fast food was eaten as a recovery food.

The Great Dying, which struck the Earth 252 million years ago, wiped out more than 96% of the world's creatures. And while extreme volcanic eruptions are commonly blamed for triggering the event, the majority of species were ultimately killed when the oceans became more acidic. The study, led by the University of Edinburgh, is the first to show that highly acidic oceans were to blame. It is the first to show that highly acidic oceans were to blame.

National Grid has revealed the UK's first new pylon for nearly 90 years. Called the T-pylon it is a third shorter than the old lattice pylons. The new pylons will be used with the Hinkley Point C nuclear power station in Somerset.

Medical professionals at the University of Arkansas for Medical Sciences in Little Rock blamed the 56-year-old man's kidney problems on the 16 8-ounce cups of iced tea he drank daily. Black tea has high levels of oxalate, a chemical known to produce kidney stones and even lead to kidney failure if consumed in excessive doses. The man was admitted to the hospital in May complaining of nausea, weakness, fatigue and body aches.

The kidneys were extracted from a 45-year-old Indian man with a genetic disorder. The condition causes fluid-filled cysts to grow in the kidneys. They expand in size, so the organs grow to 20 times their normal size. A week after the initial operation, a second kidney was removed. Both kidneys beat the previous record of 4.7lbs (2.1kg) in India.

By having signals mixed up in their brains, volunteers were made to feel that a creepy 'presence' was behind them. They counted up to four phantoms positioned where no-one was standing. Within minutes, the little wasp hunter made a startling discovery when he stumbled across the gigantic two-year-old nest. The 90-kilogram nest is measured at one metre tall and a circumference of three metres.

Women's Health Initiative in US and Million Women Study in UK found strong evidence HRT increases a woman's risk of breast, womb and ovarian cancers. Study found women who are using combined HRT have double the risk of breast cancer compared to non-users. But scientists have warned women who take combined HRT continue to have a high risk of breast cancer up to eight years after they stop treatment.

Students at St Peter's College in Melbourne have been drinking recycled water from a bubbling fountain for more than a year. The bubbler had been dispensing recycled water for 16 months. The water was treated to a standard that’s safe for watering gardens, washing clothes and flushing toilets. The principal assured students, parents and staff that the drinking fountain was shut down on April 1 and is no longer in use. The other 20 bubblers at the school have been tested and none show traces of recycled water.

Researchers from Lancaster University studied the brains of people reading passages from the Harry Potter books. They found that the common use of 'arousing words' affected parts of the brain concerned with emotion. This was because the words were used in different parts of the brain. The emotional potential of words is rated in terms of valence and arousal ratings. Valence refers to how positive or negative a word is, while arousal refers to its 'physiological intensity'

Brain scans on professional comedians reveal differences in the way brains of these'super speakers' work while talking. Super speakers showed less activity in a key area of the brain involved articulating and comprehending speech. This suggests that this group were putting less effort into the basic mechanics of speech, allowing them to devote more resources to what they were going to say next.

Researchers in North Carolina tested their theory using a 10-Hertz current on the brain's of 20 volunteers. They stimulated the brain's natural alpha wave oscillations. They then recorded the results using EEG. As well as creativity, these oscillations - or the lack of them - are linked with depression.

All land in lower 48 states was worth a combined $23trillion in 2009. Researchers estimated that land achieved its peak value of $26.2 trillion in 2006 before sliding down three trillion dollars in three years. Washington DC had the greatest land value, with a staggering $1,050,000 per acre. New Jersey, Connecticut and Massachusetts all have per acre values above $100,000.

Washington, DC-based company called United Space Structures wants to create a new space station. Their giant cylinder could apparently replace the ISS. It would rotate four times per minute to create artificial gravity, and would be 1,300ft (400 metres) long, cost £200 billion ($300 billion) and take 30 years to build. The structure would be 330ft (100 metres) in diameter and 1,310ft (400 metres) long. It would be 330ft (100 metres) in diameter and 1,310ft (400 metres) long. The station would be a'mushroom-like' appearance.

Psychologists from Goldsmiths University in London and Ohio State University in the US studied more than 13,000 twins aged nine to 16 from six countries. They found that 40 to 50 per cent of the differences in children’s motivation to learn could be explained by their genetic inheritance from their parents. The twins’ shared environment - elements such as the teachers and the family that they had in common - would be a larger factor than genetics. Genetics and non-shared-environment factors had the largest effect on the children’s motivation to learn, whereas the shared environment had negligible impact.

Scientists at Haverford College in Pennsylvania say they have spotted X-ray emissions consistent with thousands of white dwarfs at the galaxy's centre. These are stars left behind after larger ones use up their fuel. But why thousands of these stars are here remains a mystery. They are thought to be feeding on companions and are thought to be leaving behind a'mass grave' of white dwarfs.

Alan Turing wrote notes at Bletchley Park code-breaking headquarters in 1942. They paved the way for computer science and are believed to be the only extensive Turing manuscript in existence. The 56-page document was sold at auction in New York for $1,025,000 (£698,000) Turing is best known for cracking the code used by the Germans in Enigma machines during the Second World War while working at Bletchley Park, Buckinghamshire. Benedict Cumberbatch, who played Turing in The Imitation Game, said: 'The thought of holding a manuscript by him is thrilling'

Archaeologists have uncovered cremated human bones packed neatly into a cooking pot and set off at the side of the historic River Walbrook. New evidence suggests they were part of a gruesome ceremony. When 20 skulls were found in 2013 it had been thought they had got there down stream after being eroded out of a Roman cemetery. But new evidence suggests they may have been buried down stream. Scientists are now working out a connection between the skulls and Boudicca's rebels.

Governor Mary Fallin signed into law a bill approving nitrogen as an alternative method of death. The method involves pumping a chamber full of nitrogen and leaving a prisoner's body to die from lack of oxygen. Proponents tout that nitrogen killings will be 'fast and painless' for inmates - and also say the method is 'foolproof'

The study released on Thursday by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention found that about 30 percent of women who'd had a child became pregnant again within 18 months. White women had the shortest spacing — about 2 years, 2 months on average. Black and Hispanic women typically waited 212 years or longer.

Russian scientist says the distant ancestor of humans had tentacles. They lived more than 540 million years ago and used them for food. It's likely they also had a complex nervous system like we do today. Dr Elena Temereva came to her conclusion by studying the 'living fossil' Lingula anatina.

The Red Lady's remains were found in the El Mirón Cave in Cantabria, Spain. Radiocarbon dating suggests she was buried 18,700 years ago. When the remains were first uncovered they were stained with a sparking red material, later found to be red ochre from a haematite crystal. This has since faded and an engraved tombstone was found nearby. The pigment and tombstone has led researchers to speculate she was a person of status or authority and was buried in such a way to oversee her subjects.

'Marilyn Einstein' was created by superimposing a blurry picture of Marilyn Monroe over a picture of Albert Einstein drawn in fine lines. At normal screen viewing distance you should see the face of Albert Einstein. Squint your eyes or take a few steps back and Marilyn Monroe should come into view. Combining pictures of the two produces a single image which changes when the viewer moves closer or farther away from the screen.

Audi claims to have created the fuel of the future - diesel made from water and carbon dioxide. Experts used renewable energy to convert carbon dioxide and water into a form of crude oil known as 'blue crude', which was then refined into diesel. The process can be powered using renewable energy and can be achieved with an efficiency of around 70%. The new fuel is already being used to power the official car of German minister of education and research Dr Johanna Wanka.

He is accused of bringing 425,000 Jews to the Auschwitz-Birkenau complex in Nazi-occupied Poland and most immediately gassed to death. During that period, two trains would have to wait with closed doors as the first was 'processed and finished' Groening, 93, said he is'morally guilty' but not directly responsible for any deaths. He faces between three and 15 years in prison if convicted in the trial, which is scheduled through July.

US researchers claim that exact prices of goods on eBay attract higher offers than round numbers. Items with precise prices are more likely to sell quickly, but may not attract the most lucrative counter offers from sellers. Sellers who end their price with ‘00’ typically receive offers that are five to eight per cent lower than those with more specific prices.

Visual Health Studios in Colorado has developed a weight loss app called Visualize You. It processes an image of you to reveal what you would look like if you lost a specified amount weight. It then enables you to'scroll' through various weights on your way to your target weight, to see what you would look like. The app costs £1.61 ($2.40) on Android and £1.49 ($1.99) on iOS for the full version.

The water contained traces of hydrocarbons and petroleum as a result of hydraulic fracturing, which ignited. The tanker was near an injection well where fracking wastewater is pumped into the ground. No one was injured, but the facility has likely been destroyed.

Three studies have provided different theories for what happened after Earth was struck by a Mars-sized object called Theia, 4.45 billion years ago. What is agreed on, though, is that the impact actually happened. This is known as the giant impact hypothesis. The hypothesis claims the moon formed after Earth was hit by a planet the size of Mars billions of years ago. But one mystery has persisted - why are the moon and Earth so similar in their composition?

Researchers at Joint Base Lewis-McChord in Tacoma, Washington, looked at military records of 3.9million personnel who served after 9/11. They found no direct link between deployment to a war zone and elevated suicide rates. Suicide rates were similar regardless of whether or not servicemen and women were deployed to Iraq or Afghanistan.
Swiss researchers measured the temperature of 'Hot Jupiter' HD 189733b. They found the temperature reaches up to 3,000°C in the atmosphere. And wind speeds are in excess of 620 miles per hour. Findings were made using a novel technique relying on sodium signals. It was used to measure the wind, which was then 'blueshifted' to indicate it was coming towards us.

Castle Toward near Dunoon was used to prepare troops for landing at a beach and was commissioned as HMS Brontosaurus in 1942. Soldiers practised beach landings - complete with bombs, smokescreens and strafing fighters - jumping from landing craft and clambering up beach. Training at the castle was so realistic and demanding that many servicemen were killed in accidents.

Scientists at the University of Connecticut say we know how far away the source of a sound is. In a study they found that the reverberation of sound helps us locate the distance of, for example, a car passing round a bend. They said that echoes and fluctuations in volume are the cues we use to figure out the distance between us and the source of a noise. Without amplitude modulation, a person can't tell how far away a noise is.

Varvara is a 13-year-old Western gray whale. She is famous for making the longest migration of any mammal. She swam 14,000 miles (22,500km) from Russia to breeding grounds off the coast of Mexico, and back, without even stopping for a snack when she was aged nine. Her return journey raises questions about the critically endangered creature’s conservation status.

Tiny copper coin dates from the Iron Age almost 2,300 years ago. It suggests there were links between the south west of England and the Mediterranean. On one side there is a horse’s head, while the other bears the image of the goddess Tanit, the chief deity of Carthage. The find suggests that the village of Saltford, where it was found, was on a major trade route long before Roman times.

Fossils from an extinct pygmy sperm whale have shed new light on the evolution of modern day whales. The remains, which were discovered in Panama, indicate that the organ involved in sound generation and echolocation got smaller throughout the whale’s evolution. The find will help experts fill in gaps in the evolution of cetaceans.

Tokyo researchers have proposed a laser system to attach to the ISS. It would be used to shoot down pieces of debris in Earth orbit. The system would have a range of 62 miles (100km) and could target things less than 0.4 inches (1cm) in size. The impact of the laser beam on debris would create a force that reduced its velocity, causing it to fall into Earth’s atmosphere and burn up. Without going into specifics, the team says their proposal could remove ‘most’ of the centimetre-sized debris in Earth orbit within five years of operation.

The '#kyliejennerchallenge' is popular among teens desperate to emulate Kylie Jenner's bee-stung pout. Participants place their mouth over the opening of a cup, jar or other narrow vessel and suck in until the air vacuum causes their lips to swell up. The method works by way of the airlock created in the opening of the glass or jar, which increases blood flow to the lips. Problematically, the results are said to last for hours, even days, with several people complaining that they were stuck with the after-effects for a lot longer than expected.

In a $1billion lawsuit, 750 plaintiffs claim Johns Hopkins University approved and helped plan the syphilis experiment in Guatemala. The study, which ran from 1945 to 1956, deliberately infected individuals with the disease, and left some with open sores covering their bodies. The victims are now suing the university, claiming that the study was approved and monitored by Hopkins. The lawsuit, which has 750 plantiffs and includes victims and their families, is seeking $1billion.

System is being commercialised by French company Pixium Vision. It uses a technique known as 'neuromodulation' to restore sight. A surgeon first implants a small silicon chip with 150 electrodes on the retina. When the patient puts on the system's dark glasses, an integrated video camera sends images to a portable computer. A connected 'pocket processor' converts that recording into an infrared image, which the goggles will then beam into the eye. Pulses activate the electrodes in the implant, and the optic nerve carries images back to the brain.

The fort was discovered on top of Dunnicaer sea stack near Stonehaven. It was built by the Picts as a look out post on top of a 20-foot-high sea stack. Wall-mounted device creates a ‘personal sunrise’ and emits focused ultrasonic waves to wake up each person in bed individually. Wak uses a white LED to slowly illuminate the area around a sleeper’s face to gently wake them up. Device has an inbuilt sensor to detect sleepers’ body heat. It pivots and sends a directed beam of light and sound towards one sleeper. Device is affixed to the wall behind the bed and costs $250 (£167) to pre-order on Kickstarter.

Hawaii scientists say a supervoid may account for an anomaly in the cosmic microwave background radiation of the universe. In 2004 astronomers first found the 'Cold Spot' - a region 20 per cent less dense than elsewhere. The supervoid is thought to be causing a 'less-dense' region of the universe. At 1.8 billion light-years across it would be the biggest object ever found. But some 'exotic physics' is also needed to explain what's happening.

They wanted to find out whether the rodents do this as a reflex reaction, or to communicate their discomfort to others. The March jobs data raised uncertainties about the world's largest economy, which for months has been the envy of other industrialized nations. The manufacturing, building and government sectors all shed workers last month. Factories cut 1,000, snapping a 19-month hiring streak. The program was created for the DEA in 1992 and has since been discontinued. It tracked every phone call made from the United States to a country on the DEA watch list for drug trafficking. The Cheyenne Mountain Complex in Colorado was built for the North American Aerospace Command (NORAD) to direct the response to a nuclear war with the USSR during the Cold War. The complex is 2,000 feet underground and made up of 15 three-story buildings protected from nuclear blasts and seismic movement by a system of 1,000 giant springs. The complex is able to operate as an underground town for months with fresh water and food. The complex shut down nearly ten years ago as the threat from Russia seemed to subside.
Children who ate a diet high in saturated fats and cholesterol had slower reaction times and a poorer working memory, the University of Illinois study found. Children who ate the fatty diet performed worse when they were given a task-switching game to complete. The game was designed to test cognitive flexibility, which is our ability to shift attention, select information and alter our response strategy to fit the changing demands of a task.

But Thai wildlife officials began a headcount on Friday after allegations from a temple vet who complained to police that three tigers had recently disappeared from the sanctuary. Authorities say the temple has been keeping the animals without the proper paperwork and have vowed to seize them, sparking standoffs in recent weeks between officials and angry monks blocking their way.

Researchers from London and Edinburgh have developed a computer that can collate meteorological information and then produce forecasts as if they were written by a human. The computer uses a process known as 'natural language generation' (NLG) This process is used to produce readable text in English or other languages. It has the potential to one day be used in humanoid robots on our TV screens.

Promise of more sunshine comes after Friday saw the hottest day of the year so far with 21.9C observed at St James's Park in London. Met Office has predicted warmer-than-average temperatures for April, May and June of this year in its long-range forecast. But winds of more than 75mph recorded in north Wales today, and snow was also reported to have fallen on high ground in northern England. Scientists discovered a protein which helps boost the body’s immune system. The protein promotes the production of immune cells called cytotoxic T-cells. They have the ability to detect cancerous cells, hunt them down and destroy them. The therapy would use existing T-cells taken from individual patients. The patient’s cells would be removed, modified with the insertion of LEM-producing genes, and then infused back into the patients via a drip.

UK researchers studied the asteroid impact 66 million years ago. They found the heat near the impact site in Mexico was not intense enough to ignite plant material. A heat pulse lasted less than a minute, too short to set plants alight. This suggests our understanding of the mass extinction event that wiped out the dinosaurs may not be as complete as thought.

The chair in which Abraham Lincoln was shot has been on display at The Henry Ford Museum in Dearborn, Michigan, for 85 years. On April 15, it will be removed from its enclosure to be displayed in an open plaza for the 150th anniversary of the assassination. The chair has a dark stain on the back, which many visitors believe to be blood from the shooting. But historians at the museum say that the stain is oil from other people's heads who sat in the chair before Lincoln.

Never-before-seen photographs show the horror of the doomed Gallipoli landings through the eyes of soldiers. World leaders were joined by Princes Charles and Harry on the Royal Navy's flagship HMS Bulwark in Turkey's Dardanelles straits. An estimated 1,000 Allied soldiers died on the first day of the disastrous invasion until January 1916. After huge losses on both sides, the Allies successfully fooled the Turkish forces and evacuated their soldiers from the peninsula. Historian Stephen Chambers has collected more than 100 rare photographs, many taken by the troops themselves, to mark the catastrophic campaign's centenary.

Researchers in Massachusetts believe a person's keystrokes may reveal a huge amount of information about their motor skills. They have created an algorithm that can tell how effectively someone is striking a keypad. It does this by analysing something known as 'key hold time' - a measure of how long a key is pressed before being released.

Yaphank, Long Island was once home to a camp for Nazis where children could fish, swim, hunt and learn about fascism. The camp was founded in 1935 by Friends of New Germany and later became the German American Bund. The Bund in Yaphank, as it did in similar communities in Pennsylvania, Wisconsin and New Jersey, organized military demonstrations where they waved both the American and Nazi flags.

Scientists from the UK and Portugal submitted the evidence for resurrecting Brontosaurus in a study almost 300 pages long published in the open access journal PeerJ. They looked at 477 anatomical features across 81 individual dinosaurs. They used a'specimen-based protocol' to analyse each individual animal, despite its species. This allowed them to look at differences within each species, as well as between different species.

Experts believe the Molalla Log Cabin could have been built as early as 1795 - ten years before Lewis and Clark reached the Pacific Ocean. The structure's intricate construction is unlike pioneer building methods, suggesting it was created by foreigners. The way the logs are tightly interwoven, secured without nails and leaving no gaps to fill, is similar to Russian log cabins of the same time period.

Researchers studied mammoth remains found at Oimyakon in Siberia and Wrangel Island. They found that the woolly mammoths had been isolated for 5,000 years. Their population dwindled until they died out 4,500 years ago. Scientists extracted DNA from the remains of two woolly mammoths. They found that the genetics of the mammoths was consistent with inbreeding.
The tomb was discovered in Hwangnam-dong, a neighbourhood of Gyeongju City in South Korea, last December. It was the capital of ancient Silla for almost 1,000 years. The remains of the two people, including leg bones and teeth, were found in the main chamber of the tomb and are thought to have died between the ages of 20 and 30. Experts believe the tomb was intended for a noblewoman, because her body is carefully positioned to face the sky and she was buried with gold earrings.

Researchers from Nagoya University and the University of Tokyo in Japan studied stone tools used by people in the Early Ahmarian culture 40,000 years ago. They found the human tools were no more effective than Neanderthal-created tools of the same era. The findings suggest we may need to rethink the reasons humans survived Neanderthals - and that we may not have behaved as differently as we thought.

The Glass House in Chislehurst was built as a bunker for government officials during the Cold War. It was built to accomodate civil servants in the event of a nuclear attack and was built in 1951. The building fell into disrepair after the end of the Cold War but has now been transformed into a luxury home. The property, which boasts five bedrooms, a games room, drawing room, several bathrooms and a huge garden.

Survey of 19,000 people found that the more a country paid to the unemployed or sick the more likely its residents were to want a job. In Norway, which pays the highest benefits in Europe, almost 80% of people wanted a job. By contrast in Estonia, one of the least generous countries, only around 40% did.

A young woman found a mildly venomous brown tree snake in her shopping trolley. The woman pushed the trolley up an escalator to do her shopping. She realised the snake had curled itself in the corner and was hitching a ride to the store. Snake catcher Richie Gilbert was called to remove the snake and release it back into the bushland just kilometres away. Mr Gilbert said brown tree snakes are harmless and nocturnal, so they try to hide in warm areas.

Archaeologists at Boston University and the University of Bath believe this would have meant they lost out when modern humans arrived from Africa. They used computer models to model the amount of energy Neanderthals would have been able to get from their food without cooking it compared to humans that were. They found that without fire, a group of Neanderthals would have had less energy - the equivalent 12 reindeer a year - than if they did.

'Millions of tonnes' of discarded appliances are being dumped in Ghana landfills because it is cheaper to recycle them in their countries of origin. 'E-waste' worth over £34billion was discarded globally in 2014, according to a shocking report by United Nations University. The UK contributed 1.5 million tonnes of waste to the staggering 11.6 Europe generated last year - putting it behind Germany. But the continent's western nations have become a dumping ground for the world's defunct products. Some of the broken appliances even leak toxic elements such as lead and mercury which harms the local environment.

Woman, 77, was struck by lightning while sitting in her car in Boston. Days later, she noticed her vision was blurred and had burns on her scalp. She was referred to see opthalmologist Mohit Gupta, who scanned her retina. He discovered a hole in her macula, which is responsible for 90% of vision. She underwent surgery to repair the hole, after two months of poor vision.

Biologists at Jyväskylä University in Finland say eye-spots on the wings of butterflies do in fact mimic the eyes of larger and more threatening species, like owls. Scientists have long suspected the role played by eye-spots found on the wings of many butterflies were an example of mimicry, but it has never been clearly tested. They tested the theory by showing great tits pictures of owl butterflies that had been digitally altered, and watching their reaction.

The test was carried out by iPhone repairs specialist iPhoneFixed.co.uk. It used a sapphire screen from a 38mm Apple Watch for its experiment. Glass is made from synthetic sapphire, which is made by applying heat and pressure to aluminium oxide powder. It is then processed to remove impurities and is scratch-free. The screen was rubbed against a stone wall and then with a coin, before being ‘scratched’ by a key. It also withstood being rubbed with abrasive sandpaper, keyed and hit with a hammer.

Measurements made by the European space probe Philae show the comet's core isn't magnetised. Some astrophysicists have suggested that magnetism might have been responsible for aligning and then binding together rocks. But in a paper published online by the journal Science, the team led by Hans-Ulrich Auster at the Technical University of Braunschweig, Germany, said their data don't support this theory.

Dr Zoe Waller, 31, suffers from the skin condition dermatographia. Dermatographia is a type of urticaria, or hives - a raised, itchy rash. It is thought to be caused when the cells under the skin release histamines. This causes the skin to swell and is caused by friction or heat. Buzim, north west Bosnia, has more than 200 sets of twins in a population of 20,000. Local journalist Nedzip Bucelj noticed the phenomenon when his wife Emira gave birth to twins during the 1992-95 civil war. He found that during the war, there were at least 21 sets of twins born. But he believes the figure is far higher as many residents left to escape the fighting and escape poverty.

Researchers at John Hopkins Medical School in Baltimore found that people with damage to the right sagittal stratum are unable to detect sarcasm. They found that people with damage to this area of the brain were far poorer at detecting sarcasm when listening to sentences. The study found that people with damage to this area of the brain were able to identify 22 per cent of sarcastic comments.

The California Department of Water Resources has found no snow during its manual survey of the land at 6,800 feet in the Sierra Nevada in early April. The fourth consecutive year of vanishing snow spells trouble as California depends on it to melt into rivers and replenish reservoirs. The governor's order requires cities and towns to cut water use by 25 percent.

She was told she would need a further operation to correct 'deformities' to her breasts. But four days later she was told staff had confused her notes with those of two other patients, and she'd never had the disease. Rosetta launched into space in 2004 and entered orbit around 67P/Churyumov-Gerasimenko in August 2014. It successfully released the Philae lander from its grip to land on the comet. But when it first made contact with the surface it failed to fire harpoons that would have kept it attached to the comet. This resulted in it bouncing to a height of 0.62 miles (1km) above the comet. It then bounced again, but at a much lower altitude. Esa said it took until Monday to get the spacecraft back into ‘normal’ status.

The probe swooped to within 8.6 miles (14 km) of comet 67P’s surface on Saturday. It was able to capture a four image montage showing the two lobes of the icy comet in incredible detail. The top right frame offers a stunning view onto Hapi, the comet’s ‘neck’ region that is littered with boulders. The view also gives a detailed look at the numerous, curved markings visible on the smooth surface.

Flakka can be injected, snorted, smoked, swallowed or taken with other drugs. It is usually made from the chemical alpha-PVP, the synthetic version of the stimulant cathinone, the same type of chemical that is used to make bath salts. Flakka resembles a mix of crack cocaine and meth and it has a strong odor like a sweaty sock.

Scientists at Sheffield University identified six different types of obese person. They say they hope the distinction will allow for tailor-made treatments. BMI is a recognised measure of obesity but does not account for variation. Largest cluster was 'younger healthy females' - also the youngest group. 'Heavy drinking males' showed similar characteristics, but consumed a high level of alcohol. 'Unhappy anxious middle-aged' group had high levels of insomnia, anxiety, depression and fatigue.

Schieffer, who has worked for CBS since 1969, revealed he was stepping down last Wednesday. Schieffer, who has worked for CBS since 1969, has been the network's chief Washington correspondent since 1992.

Historians have long believed this was result of an epileptic attack. But new research suggests that the Roman general may in fact have been suffering from a series of mini-strokes that affected both his mental and physical state. The Colima volcano in Mexico erupted in 1576 and is one of the most active in the country. It is thought to have thrown ash up to 1.8 miles into the atmosphere before releasing a powerful bolt of lightning. Engineers at the University of Sheffield's Faculty of Engineering used tampons to test for sewage pollution in a river. They found that cotton products absorb chemicals commonly used on toilet paper, laundry detergents and shampoos. The super absorbent properties of tampons could be used to detect pipes that shunt sewage into streams instead of treatment plants. They could shed light on undetectable misplumbed pathways.

Scientists from Clarkson University in Potsdam, New York, claim that older buildings where ghost sightings are reported have poor air quality from pollutants like toxic mould. 'Ghosts' tend to be sighted in old buildings, which are often more likely to have damp and mould problems. Exposure to toxic mould spores has been linked with mood swings, hyperactivity, and irrational anger, as well as cognitive impairment.

Scientists at the University of Wisconsin-La Crosse warned Bikram yoga can raise a person's body temperature and heart rate to dangerous levels. A typical 90-minute class lasts for 90 minutes and is performed in a room heated to 40°C (105°F), with 40 per cent humidity. The risk for heat-related illness, such as heat stroke, increases at 40°C (104°F)

Archaeologists have discovered evidence that Neanderthals regularly inhabited the Cave of Llenes, near Senterada in Catalonia. The remains of cave bears, hyenas, leopards, wolves and badgers have been found in the cave and were apparently also living there. Scratches on the walls and signs of hibernation nests suggest they were living alongside Neanderthals 200,000 years ago.

Researchers focused on POMC neurons, which are a structure called the hypothalamus, that send and receive signals to regulate appetite. When POMC neurons are absent, or not working properly, animals and humans grow dangerously obese. The team, led by the University of Michigan, looked at how a protein called a transcription factor, and two small stretches of DNA called enhancers, act as triggers for the Pomc gene. All three regulate how often and when the POMC cells use the gene to create the signal molecules that then go out to the body.

Hedione activates part of the hypothalamus - an area of the brain responsible for triggering the release of sex hormones in women. Christian Dior fragrance, Eau Savage, was the first to use it in 1966. Scientists analysed brain activity when a person smelled Hedione. They found Hedione activated brain areas in the limbic system, which is responsible for emotions, memory and motivation.

In America, sales of tooth whitening products have risen 300 per cent since 1996. The trend for excessive bleaching has grown so commonplace there that dentists have coined a new word for it - 'bleachorexia' Symptoms include burning gums, tooth infection and the conviction that, no matter how much a tooth has been whitened, it could be paler still. Researchers at the University of Huddersfield have created a technique which can distinguish between the genetic fingerprints of identical twins. Identical twins start life with the same genes because they come from the same fertilised egg which divides into two embryos. But as they age different life experiences, such as smoking or diet, create variations in the number of hydrogen bonds in the DNA. This can be caused by smoking, sunshine, exposure to chemicals, or different diets.

Four former Fort Lauderdale police officers have been fired following an investigation into a racist video and text messages. Prosecutors say they've dropped 12 felony cases, 19 criminal misdemeanor cases and one juvenile case involving one or more of the officers. The arresting officers in the cases, which include burglary, cocaine possession and aggravated assault with a firearm, are no longer on the police force. All of the four officers committed misconduct involving racist texts 'exchanged among themselves and former police officers', police chief Frank Adderley said.

Esa’s Rosetta spacecraft has captured stunning images of a dust jet erupting from comet 67P Churyumov-Gerasimenko. Jet may have been caused by a wave of heat reaching ice trapped under the surface, causing an explosion of material. But it is unusual, because such activity has only been spotted on the day-side of the comet - not the night.

Scientists at UCLA examined the brains of 90 women, 44 of whom took the Pill, and 46 who experienced natural cycles. Found the lateral orbitofrontal cortex and the posterior cigulate cortex were thinner in those women taking the contraception. This could account for increased anxiety and depressive symptoms experienced by some women on the Pill.

The game was created by Network365 and is available for free on Facebook, Android, iOS and on desktop browsers. On each board, one of the squares is a slightly different shade of the same colour and the aim is to find this odd square by tapping it with your finger or clicking it with the mouse. Scores lower than 11 are poor, scores between 15 and 20 is 'lower than average', 21 to 30 is considered normal or average, and a score higher than 31 means your eyesight is 'great'

University of Nebraska researcher has revealed why stress is bad for you. Limited periods of stress are good, as they release the hormone cortisol. This is useful in helping you recover from very tense situations. But too much will lower your immune system and make your bones fragile. The science of stress was explained in a video by Dr Raychelle Burks. She says stress is good for your immune system and slows bone growth. But staying stressed for too long can have negative effects.

Centrepiece, the 11-bedroom Chyknell Hall, was built in 1814 and has only changed hands twice since. It also boasts a swimming pool, tennis court, stables - and even its own cricket green. Estate, described as 'pinnicle of residential tree', offers 57 acres of woodland and more than 500 acres of adjoining sporting rights.

Researchers at Yahoo Labs in California have created a sensor that can recognise the shape of your ear or any other body part. Called Bodyprint, the technology turns a standard touchscreen into a biometric scanner removing the need to specialist hardware. It can also be used to add multiple users to a single device. So, for example, if something required dual identification then both people could provide it. There's no news yet on when the feature might be made available to manufacturers, but the team says their next step is to continue testing.

The BBC will air a two-hour, real-time documentary following a canalboat as it pootles its way along a stretch of the Kennet and Avon Canal. There is no presenter, narrator, dialogue or music, so all viewers will hear are the sounds of the boat's engine, the lapping of the water and the local birdsong. The film was shot on a sunny day last month and will air on May 5 as part of the BBC Four Goes Slow series of deliberately unrushed programmes.

Life Paint is a temporary light reflective spray for cyclists. It was created by a Swedish start-up and is invisible by daylight. It reflects light in the same direction as a car’s headlights to illuminate objects. The paint is so popular that the trial cans up for grabs at certain cycling shops in London were snapped up in days. Some of these are now on sale on eBay for £45 ($66) at the time of writing.

Study found overweight people are less likely to develop dementia. Being overweight reduced the risk of premature death by six per cent. Being underweight increased the dementia risk by 39 per cent. Lead researcher said it was no excuse to pile on the pounds.

Scientists at Brandeis University in Massachusetts believe all-nighters to cram for an exam won't work because the process converting short-term memory to long-term memory is best carried out when a person is asleep. The team of graduate students, Paula Haynes and Bethany Christmann, believe this all takes place in a simple system, like fruit flies. They believe this all takes place in a section of the fly's brain called the mushroom body - which is where our memories are stored.

The 11 former Atlanta Public Schools teachers were convicted Wednesday of racketeering for their role in a scheme to inflate students' scores on standardized exams. The defendants - including teachers, a principal and other administrators - were accused of falsifying test results to collect bonuses or keep their jobs. The educators fed answers to students or erased and changed the answers on tests after they were turned in, the court was told. The person accused of benefiting the most from the conspiracy, Superintendent Beverly Hall, died of breast cancer over the course of the trial. The 11 will be sentenced on April 8 and could face up to 20 years in prison for the racketeering charges.

Vincent Cianni, 63, has spent three years traveling the U.S. photographing and interviewing gay veterans and servicemen. He embarked on the project, Gays in the Military, to better understand why homosexuals would enlist in the military. Cianni's photos show commonalities between the subjects despite their different journeys, from a 92-year-old WW2 veteran to young soldiers who recently returned from Afghanistan. A major turning point for gay people in the military came in 2011 with the overturning of Dont Ask Don't Tell (DADT), a discouraging policy signed by Bill Clinton in 1993.

150 business leaders have signed letter warning against a 'change in course' Among new signatories is Simon Woodroffe, founder of Yo! Sushi. Others include executives from two FTSE-100 firms and 10 from FTSE-250.
Primatologists at Iowa State University recorded 300 hunts by chimps in Sénégal. They found female chimps were using tools to capture prey in 60% of the observations. Male chimps tended to capture larger prey and use their hands. Findings suggest early female humans were perhaps the first to begin fashioning simple tools to help them catch prey.

Deep brain stimulation is already used to treat Parkinson's disease. Scientists have now found it can boost memory by forming new brain cells. A 'pacemaker' is inserted into the brain through holes drilled in the skull. It sends electrical impulses to specific parts of the brain and has been shown to provide benefits for a range of conditions including chronic pain, major depression and obsessive compulsive disorder.

Security researchers have discovered a way to intercept a person's fingerprints. They are on a Samsung Galaxy S5 running Android 4.4 and older. The flaw means that once a hacker has access they can monitor data recorded by built-in sensors, including the fingerprint scanner. When a fingerprint is scanned it is encrypted. Hackers typically can't access this encrypted file, but the flaw allows them to collect scans from the sensor before being encrypted.

Scientists have found deep water gas hydrates in the Arctic that are reservoirs for abiotic methane. The gas forms through a process called serpentinisation. Serpentinisation occurs when seawater reacts with hot mantle rocks. It is 20 times more effective in trapping heat than carbon dioxide.
Police in Rhein Erft, Germany received a bizarre phone call explaining that a large kangaroo was spotted 'happily' hopping through a field. They initially dismissed the call and assumed it was an April Fools prank. They later discovered that the call was in fact serious and found the animal in a field in Bruhl. The animal's owners later contacted police and it is believed that the animal's fencing was damaged due to severe storms.
Alan Turing wrote notes on 'Leibniz notation dx/dy' in handwritten notebook. 56-page book bought in Cambridge contains Turing's thoughts on tricky equation. 'I find [it] extremely difficult to understand in spite of it having been the one I understood the best once!', he wrote. It was written at Bletchley Park code-breaking headquarters in 1942. It is believed to be the only extensive Turing manuscript known to exist.

The Rubber Bowl in Akron, Ohio, was built in 1939 and served as the home for the University of Akron's football team for 65 years. The stadium hosted acts like the Rolling Stones, Ringo Starr, Black Sabbath, Simon & Garfunkel, Alice Cooper, Bon Jovi, Van Halen, Metallica, Tom Petty, Bob Dylan, The Grateful Dead and Aretha Franklin. The island of St Helena was discovered by Portuguese explorer Juan de Nova in 1502. It lay undiscovered for around 14 million years and has its own unique flora and fauna untouched by the outside world. The island, which is smaller than central Paris has just 4,200 inhabitants - and 850 live in the small capital of Jamestown. Early next year, an airport will open on the island. The £218 million project will make this British Overseas Territory no longer quite so isolated.

The Rev. Robert H. Schuller, 88, died early Thursday in California at the age of 88. He beamed his upbeat messages on faith and redemption to millions from his landmark Crystal Cathedral. In 2013, he was diagnosed with a tumor in his esophagus that had spread to his lymph nodes and began treatment. The soaring, glass-paned Crystal Cathedral — the touchstone of Schuller's storied ministry — was sold to the Roman Catholic Diocese of Orange in 2011. Schuller lost a legal battle the following year to collect more than $5 million from his former ministry for claims of copyright infringement and breach of contract.

Bill Parker, 34, of Gulfport, Mississippi, was mowing his lawn on April 19 when a metal fence wire shot up his nose and into his head. The wire was as thick as a heavy-duty nail and dodged all of Parker's important nerves and arteries. He went to Memorial Hospital for treatment and a CT scan revealed the wire had been shot up his nostril and lodged in his sinus cavity. Dr Timothy Haffey removed the wire in a 20-minute sinus surgery which took 20 minutes and entailed making an incision on Parker's upper lip.

Nasa's Landsat 7 satellite captured the stunning show from space. It shows 'ribbons' of sand and patterned stripes known as linear dunes. The dunes are known to measure as long as 99 miles (160km) One theory is that the linear dunes are created by helical roll vortices. These are long rolls of air that spiral, or rotate one way before rotating another. As the wind moves and switches direction it causes the sand to move accordingly and create grooves and ridges in the sand.

The new 'Skywalk' observation deck has opened to the public in Yunyang County, southwest China. The cantilevered platform in Chongqing has a 720 degree view from a vantage point that stands nearly 4,000 feet above sea level. Its viewing area protrudes nearly 90ft from the cliff face at the Longgang scenic area - more than 16ft longer than the Grand Canyon in America.

US scientists have found a way to use discarded corn husks and stalks to make cheap hydrogen fuel that doesn't pollute the environment like fossil fuels. The breakthrough could one day see the fuel being produced locally and drivers stopping to refuel their vehicles at roadside bioreactors. The gas is expensive and is not easy to store, meaning more research is needed for hydrogen cars to become mainstream.

Radar images from Europe's Sentinel-1a satellite have revealed the aftermath of the Nepal earthquake in unrivalled detail. The information from the satellites has been transformed into an interferogram, which provides a colourful view of the Earth's land mass. Scientists have discovered Mount Everest shrank by about one inch due to the land that was shaken in the natural disaster. An area 75 miles (120km) by 30 miles (50km) has lifted up 3.2ft (1 metre) from the ground around the capital, Kathmandu.

The three-year-old dog was spotted on April 15 near Glenn Highway and then again last Friday near Rev. Tim Carrick's United Protestant Presbyterian Church. Carrick set up a cage trap in the woods between his home and the church and used four bowls of dog kibbles, a pot of chicken stock, liverwurst and a motion activated camera to help capture Sarabi.
The Sainsbury's app is currently in development and will be trialled in Wandsworth later this year. It lets homeowners gradually build up a list of items they need over a week. When that shopper enters a local store, a map will appear on the phone showing the customer where their groceries are. As customers scan their household items, a live pricing tool will show their list with current store prices. These prices will update automatically if an item goes on sale.

Larry Kramer, 79, says he believes what's written in his history book is true though he is selling it as fiction to avoid legal troubles. In Volume One of his two part book 'The American People,' Kramer says that Abraham Lincoln was gay and his killer John Wilkes Booth was actually Lincoln's spurned gay lover. Kramer says that the motive for Lincoln's murder was not Booth's anger over the Civil War but was his unrequited love for the former president.

This is significantly lower than widely-used Australian Bureau of Statistics predictions of between 1.7 and 1.8 per cent. A University of Cologne scientist led research proposing a new theory. It suggests temperatures at Earth's equator were -40°C (-40°F) 2.4 billion years ago. The reasons why the whole planet was frozen are not understood. But it could have implications for finding life on frozen moons like Europa. This could help explain a period in Earth’s history known as the Great Oxygen Transition, 2.2 billion years ago. And he said a drop in CO2 levels was likely the cause of Earth turning into a snowball.

Tesla founder Elon Musk unveiled the Powerwall device at a press conference in California last night. It is three feet wide and four feet tall, weighs 220lbs, and can be installed either on an outside or inside wall. The daily use version has a capacity of 7 kilowatt-hours, which is around a quarter of a home's daily usage. The device could be in homes by the end of summer and will be able to store electricity at night when it is cheaper.

Biologists studied the healing process at a molecular level using electron microscopes to examine skin as it repairs itself. They found skin cells appear to attach to each other using tiny tubes that then pull them together so they interlock together like a zip. Findings could help in the development of new treatments for wounds that could speed up this process.

Genetic analysis from ancient human remains shows that European populations were still evolving until relatively recently. Researchers found that hunter gatherers living in Spain up to 8,500 years ago still had dark skin. It was not until 7,800 years ago, when the first farmers migrated from the Near East through Turkey, that two key genes that provide lighter skin appeared.

Martin Burgess Clock B is based on design by John Harrison from 1800s. Clock was designed to solve problem of determining longitude at sea. It has been part of trial at Royal Observatory, Greenwich, for 100 days. Time was measured using radio-controlled clock and BT speaking clock.

Research led by Dr Haimin Wang from the New Jersey Institute of Technology has revealed the first high-resolution footage of a solar flux rope. The twisting magnetic fields can be seen writhing around a central axis, and the rope eventually causes a bright flash - a solar flare. The new footage was revealed in a paper in Nature Communications led by Dr Haimin Wang. It is hoped the study could help increase understanding on how they form - and how they are related to solar eruptions.
A Reuters investigation revealed the Bill, Hillary and Chelsea Clinton Foundation had misreported millions of dollars in donations from foreign nations. The charity announced that it would refile more than five years of tax documents. The discovery came as separate financial reviews found that previously unreported foreign businesses either donated money directly to the family foundation or paid Bill to speak while their countries were doing official business with the State Department. The Clinton Foundation was barred by an agreement from accepting money from foreign governments it wasn't already in business while Mrs. Clinton was in President Barack Obama's cabinet.

The USS Oklahoma capsized on December 7, 1941, after being hit by nine torpedoes. The ship capsized and 429 sailors and Marines onboard were killed. Only 35 were identified in the years immediately after. Hundreds were buried as unknowns at cemeteries in Hawaii. In 1950, they were reburied as unknowns at the National Memorial Cemetery of the Pacific - also known as the Punchbowl - inside a volcanic crater in Honolulu.

Police have identified the driver as Daniel Robert Frank, 28, who was arrested earlier this month for an unrelated offence.

Derby can secure a play-off spot if they win and both Brentford (away to Reading) and Wolves (away to Wigan) fail to win. Sheffield United (away to Leyton Orient) and Chesterfield (home to Bristol City) will be guaranteed play-off places with wins or if Rochdale fail to win. Burton Albion will be promoted as champions if they win and Shrewsbury (home to Cheltenham) lose. Bristol Rovers (home to Alfreton) will be promoted as champions if they win and Barnet (home to Gateshead) will be promoted as champions if they win.

Scientists at the Scripps Institution of Oceanography, in La Jolla, California, recorded the mysterious ‘Antarctic BW29 signal’ more than 1,000 times. They conclude that it’s unique in the composition of sounds making the signal and in timing. But the song belong to a strap-toothed whale, a southern bottlenosed whale or a Gray’s beaked whale, according to the study.

Experts from the Centre for International Research in the Humanities and Social Sciences (CIRHUS) in New York City studied neolithic ornaments to understand how farming spread. They found that Northern Europeans in the Neolithic period initially rejected the practice of farming, which was spreading throughout the rest of the continent. Findings show farming enabled groups of people to move away from foraging and hunting as a means of survival.

Scientists have found the skeleton of a giant prehistoric predatory bird. They say it is the most complete skeleton of a 'terror bird' to be discovered. The bird has been named Llallawavis scagliai after a naturalist. It was so well preserved scientists have been able to study part of its auditory system and its trachae. The hearing of the bird was below average compared to birds living today.

They claim the stone is between 300 and 320 million years old. The screw-like shape may actually be the reversed-shape of the creature, which gradually dissolved while the rock formed around it. Some people claim it may be proof of a lost human civilisation. But experts suggest that the ‘screw’ is in fact a fossilised sea creature called a crinoid.

Officials said that the pilot had the wrong radio frequency to turn on the lights on the main, 13,000-foot runway.

Rhondda Tunnel, which runs 1,000 feet beneath Welsh hills, was closed in 1968. It was closed as part of Beeching cutbacks, which spelled end for thousands. But engineers are due to visit the 3,148m tunnel next week to see if it is safe. It would be one of the longest cycle tunnels in the world, second only to the 4,000m Snoqualmie Tunnel near Seattle in the U.S.

The aim of DiCaprio and his partners is to rehabilitate the ecosystem of the area, which has endured deterioration from over-fishing, deforestation and an eroding coastline. The rare albino bottlenose dolphin has been making waves at the Taiji Whale Museum in southern Japan. While bottlenose dolphins are typically grey, the mammal is completely white– apart from the quirky tendency to turn pink when it's feeling angry, sad or even embarrassed. The phenomenon results from the animals thin skin, which means its blood vessels can cause a change in skin tone depending on their emotional state. The rare specimen is believed to be only the second one ever put on display in an aquarium after it was purchased from fishermen last year.

Blue Bell Ice Cream has suspended operations at an Oklahoma production facility that officials had previously connected to a foodborne illness linked to the deaths of three people. Last month, the company and health officials said a 3-ounce cup of ice cream contaminated with listeriosis was traced to a plant in Broken Arrow, Oklahoma. The now-recalled ice cream product - cups of chocolate, strawberry and vanilla - is not sold in retail locations and is shipped in bulk to 'institutional accounts' such as hospitals in 23 states that comprise less than 5 per cent of the company's sales.

St Catherine's Island, off the coast of Tenby, will be accessible via footbridge. The historic building will be joined to the mainland thanks to a 328ft footbridge. Scientists are working towards digitally recreating the cognitive abilities of the Apis Mellifera or European Honeybee. Their final aim is to build a robot that thinks, senses and acts just like the tiny insects. The artificial brain is being created by the Green Brain Project. It is hoped the remote controlled machines could be used to pollinate crops or even assist on search and rescue missions.

Dawn Williamson, 39, was crippled by her 30-year phobia of snakes. Before today, she could not even confront a plastic snake without panicking. She would obsessively check her toilet for the reptiles every day. But today she was cured of her phobia by therapists Nik and Eva Speakman. They broke down Dawn’s phobia with their no-nonsense approach. At the beginning of the show, Dawn broke down in tears at the mere sight of a plastic snake, which sent her heart rate soaring. At the end of the show she was able to touch a real-life 9ft Burmese python.

A study has revealed that 30 percent of Australians complain about their lack of sleep on a daily basis. The average adult needs around eight hours of sleep per night with a range of seven to nine hours. Any less than six or any more than ten hours is unusual for the standard person. Hydrogen fuel is appealing for use in cars but requires huge amounts of energy. Scientists at the University of Bath and Yale University created the invention. It uses a newly designed molecular catalyst to split water in an electrolyser. This creates clean and storable hydrogen fuel, which is cheaper. The catalyst is more efficient at performing the crucial oxidation half of the chemical reaction than any other existing material.

Common dolphins were once a rare sight in the Hebrides, preferring warmer waters found further south. But monitoring by Hebridean Whale and Dolphin Trust teams has seen the number of encounters increase by 68 per cent over the past 12 years. Warmer water species appear to be colonising new areas further north or closer to shore, the trust said.

Researchers at the Natural History Museum in London and University College London have found evidence that the human bones found in Gough's Cave in Somerset had the flesh cut from them. They also found tooth marks on many of the bones, which were discovered in the cave during excavations between 1880 and 1992. Findings suggest prehistoric humans living in the late Ice Age indulged in ritual cannibalism, perhaps as a macabre way to revere their dead kin.

Riff lets you film videos and upload them to the app and Facebook. Friends and strangers can then film relevant clips and attach them to the end. Videos can be shared on social networks, over email and in messaging apps. Each video has a counter that shows how many clips are attached. It doesn't reveal what the maximum number of clips in a project is, but each clip can be no longer than 10 seconds.

Map allows astronomers to'stand' on planetary surfaces. It covers the vast crater-strewn highland region of the red planet. It covers parts of the Ares Vallis outflow channel and the chaotic Aram Chaos region. The mosaic extends over 1,120 miles (1800km) from north to south and 810 miles (1,300km) from east to west.

Scientists used a new technique to reconstrcut colourful patterns on 28 fossilised cone snail shells that are up to 6.6 million years old. Under ultraviolet light traces of pigment left in the shells are revealed. This allows scientists to look millions of years into the past to reconstruct shell patterns and colours as above.

Lawrencium was first discovered in 1961 by nuclear scientist Ernest Lawrence. It is notoriously difficult to make and only exists for a few seconds at a time. This has made the element, which can only be generated in particle accelerators, extremely difficult to study. Researchers have now been able to test how much energy is required to strip an electron from an atom of the rare metal.

Federal health officials say 106 passengers and six crew members aboard the Celebrity Infinity cruise ship were sickened by the gastrointestinal illness norovirus. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) said in a Monday news release there were 2117 total passengers on the ship and 964 total crew members. The agency said the main symptoms for those affected were diarrhea and throwing up. The ship was on its journey from March 29 to April 13. Symptoms of norovirus include vomiting, diarrhea, fever and body aches.

Researchers from the Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology in Leipzig, Germany, found spores of several mushroom species embedded in her teeth. The Red Lady of El Mirón was buried in an elaborate grave in the El Mirón cave in Cantabria, Spain, 18,700 years ago. Her teeth bore the remains of plant pollen, fungi and animals. Violet Pietrok, from Portland, Oregon, was born with frontonasal dysplasia, a malformation of the face and head that is developed in the womb. The condition caused a widening of Violet's facial features, specifically with her nose, which had no cartilage, and the space between her eyes. She also had a large central cleft in her face and a growth over her left eye. Plastic surgeon-in-chief Dr. John Meara spent months preparing for Violet's surgery, specifically with molds of her skull that were made using a 3D printer.

Italian Alex Bellini will live atop an iceberg in Greenland starting next year. He will live inside a contained ball, with no means to escape for 12 months. The capsule will be 10ft (three metres) wide and could fit 10 people. But Mr Bellini will remove all of the seats apart from one for himself. He'll also have exercise equipment, such as a stationary bike, and supplies for the year such as food and water.

The number of uninsured Americans is now at a record low. When tracking began in 2008 roughly 14per cent of citizens were uninsured, peaking at 18per cent in the third quarter of 2013. For the first three months of this year the rate dropped to 11.9per cent. Coverage gains from 2014-2015 translate to about 3.6 million fewer adults uninsured since the fall, before open enrollment got under way.

Research carried out by the charity Medical Detection Dogs in Milan. Dogs sniffed urine samples of 360 men with prostate cancer and 540 without. Scientists found dog one got it right in 98.7% of cases, while for dog two this was 97.6%. Prostate cancer is the most common cancer in men in the UK.
University of Cambridge scientist has revealed his green source of energy. By using just moss he is able to generate enough power to run a clock. He said panels of plant material could power appliances in our homes. And the technology could help farmers grow crops where electricity is scarce. Dr Paolo Bombelli presented his research at a preview of the Pint of Science festival, which is taking place from 18 to 20 May. He is adamant that regular moss could provide an additional source of renewable energy to complement others that are available.

EU has been investigating US search engine for five years. It has been investigating complaints that it abuses its dominance in Europe. But proceedings have stalled on three previous occasions. Now EU is asking companies who filed confidential complaints for permission to publish them, so officials can begin to build a case against the firm. If found to have been behaving unfairly, Google could be fined ten per cent of its annual revenues, which would be more than £4 billion based on last year's performance.

Some owners of the coveted Apple Watch have found that it malfunctions if worn on tattooed wrists. Dark, vibrant ink seems to cause the watch’s heart sensor to lose connection and give inaccurate readings. This is because the heart sensor reads a pulse by measuring light absorption through the skin - a process called photoplethysmography. Apple has yet to comment on the problem, despite there being speculation that the apparent fault could also stop some people using Apple Pay.

Bath Abbey was granted planning permission for the £18million scheme two years ago. Engineers plan to excavate ancient crypts below the church to tap into a Roman drain where 850,000 litres of natural spring water empties every day. They hope to divert the warm water through a network of underground pipes to provide a world-first natural underfloor heating system. The idea is that if waste water was harnessed correctly and converted, it could produce 1.5 megawatts of continuous energy.

The Variety Theater in Cleveland, Ohio, was once a buzzing music venue but closed down after a gig in 1984. The ceiling cracked and pieces of plaster fell on the audience - ending the concert and the life of the venue. The 20,000 sq ft main stage hosted the likes of Metallica, the Dead Kennedy's and R.E.M. before Motorhead's fatal performance. The venue has stayed abandoned and hidden from public eye until now, thirty years later, a photographer has captured these stunning images.

Researchers at Stanford University School of Medicine have hailed the research a 'tour de force' They believe the laboratory-engineered antibodies could eradicate primary tumours, as well as distant metastases. The process relies on the same mechanism as that which causes animals' bodies to reject organ transplants.

He became inspired to start his second project, Salty Girls, starring women with the genetic disease. The project's name is derived from the fact that people with CF have more salt in their sweat compared with those who do not have the disorder.

Jasmine Midgley was born with a birthmark that blocked her airways. At just 10 weeks old, the harmless mark had started growing into her throat. It closed over her airways, almost closing over her airways and choking her. Her parents were told she had bronchiolitis - a common infection of the upper airways. But antibiotics failed to help her cold-like symptoms and she was kept overnight. Her life-threatening problem was only detected the next day when a new doctor came onto the ward and noticed the birthmark was cutting off her air supply.

The image was captured over Jaibru in Australia by an off-duty emergency services officer. It shows a bolt of lightning soaring from the top of a cloud before looping back on itself and striking the ground. Upwards lightning is very rare - estimates suggest less than 1% of lightning strikes travel in an ‘upwards’ direction. Storm chaser Dan Robinson believes 'looped' lighting may instead be a trick of perspective, based on where a viewer is stood. He said if part of a bolt is coming straight at you, it will appear to loop back on itself even when it's not.

It has been in use for more than 70 years, but this is the first time that this side effect has been discovered. Previous research had shown that acetaminophen works not only on physical pain, but also on psychological pain.

Pennsylvania scientists have found evidence that we may not be alone. They found 50 galaxies that emit unusually high levels of radiation. This could be because aliens are harnessing the power of stars. However, further research is needed to confirm that is the case. The findings were made using Nasa’s orbiting Wide-Field Infrared Survey Explorer (Wise) telescope. This telescope is perfect for detecting mid-infrared radiation that an advanced alien race might be emitting.

Called the Michigan Micro Mote, it is the first complete computer system measuring as small as two millimeters across. It contains solar cells that power the battery with ambient light. Mindfulness-based cognitive therapy (MBCT) has similar recurrence rates as anti-depressants, a study found. Over two years, relapse rates were 44 per cent in the MBCT group compared to 47 per cent in the medication group. This suggests it offers an 'alternative treatment' for those averse to the idea of taking drugs.

Abramovich has been trying to buy a home in the fashionable Neve Tzedek quarter of Tel Aviv since 2008.

The 'goblins' are scientifically known as 'hoodoos' - rock protrusions consisting of relatively soft rock topped by harder stone. The softer rock has been removed by wind and water, leaving thousands of unique constructions. The site also boasts some of the darkest skies in the world offering visitors the chance to gaze at stars, planets and distant galaxies.

Bed was left in car park of former Redland House Hotel in Hough Green, Chester. It was dumped by builders who were renovating the property in 2010. Oblivious to its true value and historical significance, they dismantled it. It was snapped up for £2,200 by a four-poster bed specialist from Northumberland. TV historian Jonathan Foyle has spent years trying to prove its historical roots. He has now revealed DNA testing on the bed's timber proved it once belonged to King Henry VII. Bed is now reportedly worth up to £20million, although it is not up for sale.

The fossil is being sold by Hong Kong-based experts Evolve. It is more than 95 per cent complete bone, is 9.2ft (2.8 metres) long, 5.2ft (1.6 metres) high and 4.6ft (1.4 metres) wide. Earth oscillates for months following a seismic event. Earth is vibrating at extremely low frequencies all of the time. Scientists studied ocean waves at the bottom of the seabed to find out why they collide and create a constant hum. This means earthquakes, colliding oceans and long waves all combine to create the Earth's constant hum.

Life expectancy for older women has fallen after decades of rises. Predicted life spans of women aged 65, 75, 85 and 95 fell in 2012. It is the first time since 1995 that falls in all four age groups were recorded. Average 75-year-old woman could expect to live another 13 years and five weeks. For a woman aged 85, expected span was six years and 42 weeks.

Scientists from the University of Bologna in Italy, used CT scans of teeth found at Riparo Bombrini in western Ligurian Alps and Grotta di Fumane in western Lessini Mountains in Italy. They found that the enamel on the crown of the teeth was thicker than that found on Neanderthal teeth and it was more similar in morphology to modern humans. Findings suggest the arrival of this modern human culture that followed the arrival of these first modern humans in Europe 40,000 years ago played a role in the demise of Neanderthals.

One in five young professionals now considers themselves to have a drinking problem, a new poll found. Nearly half of young workers think it is acceptable to regularly get drunk on a night out, compared to a fifth of the general population. More than a third of 18-24-year-olds said they had got so drunk they could not remember most of their night out. One in 20 admitted to driving themselves home drunk and one in ten said they got in a car with someone they knew was intoxicated.

The first ever mid-air refuelling of an unmanned aircraft was today. The Salty Dog 502 vehicle is one of two Unmanned Carrier Air Vehicle demonstrators (UCAS-D) on the X-47B program. Gold Coast City Council will finally be able to shut down illegal party houses in suburban areas after the state government approved new planning powers. There are more than 700 party houses across the city, which are often used for unruly weekend-long parties. The new powers, approved by Deputy Premier and Planning Minister Jackie Trad, means there is now an official and legal definition of a party house. If an illegal party house is reported to the council, authorities will be able to force the owner of the property to apply for a development application.

Researchers at New York University have been trying to gain an understanding about how the brain stores memories for 'emotionally neutral events' This is because emotion affects activity in brain regions involved in emotional processing - particularly the amygdala and striatum. Emotion also increases the strength of our memory over time - a process called consolidation.

Fast food giant Chipotle is making a fresh start and stepping away from using GMOs (genetically modified organisms) as ingredients. Steve Ells, the company's co-CEO and founder, discussed the new development with CNN Money. Ells said in the interview that the company has 68 total ingredients and another company's burrito features upwards of 80. Rice, meat marinades, chips, salsa, and tortillas will not be made with GMOs -- with non-GMO corn, sunflower oil and rice bran oil now featuring as ingredients.
Tewksbury Police Department came under attack by hackers in December. They encrypted vital records on their computer using a malware program called CryptoLocker. The program scrambles the data on the computer and demands money. The only files that were not corrupted were 18 months old. Police were forced to pay the ransom in the untraceable digital currency.

The two men that can be seen on the boat are shark experts Jeff Kurr and Andy Casagrande. They can be seen panicking as the great white uses its strong jaws and tail to shake the boat, causing it to sway dangerously.

The Bergen-Belsen death camp was liberated by British and Canadian troops in 1945, but was burned to the ground. It was the final resting place for 50,000 Jews, Gypsies, homosexuals, Nazi opponents and those with disabilities. Reverend Charles Martin King Parsons, one of a handful of British Army chaplains who helped liberate it, took the pictures. He was one of a handful of British Army chaplains who helped to cure the sick, and offer last comforts to those beyond saving.

The attraction, at Fancesa limestone quarry in Sucre, Bolivia, comprises some 462 trails made up of 5,055 prints. Some of the prints are more than a metre in length, indicating the size of some of the vast beasts that roamed the area. The imprinted rock was once horizontal before being pushed upwards by tectonic activity. The imprinted rock dried in the hot season and was preserved before more mud and possibly volcanic ash covered and preserved them.

Researchers from Stanford University used data from 6,588 registered users to determine which colours are most commonly associated with which letters. They then compared these colour-letter matches to fridge magnets sold by Fisher-Price between 1971 and 1990. Results revealed that at least six per cent (400 out of the 6588 participants) learnt'many of their matches' from the toy. For participants born between 1970 and 1985, the prevalence of synesthesia apparently learned from the toy can exceed 15 per cent.

The total lunar eclipse will transform the moon on Saturday night. It will be visible in the skies of North America, Asia and Australia. Scientists in Colorado have found evidence for a new solar season cycle. Every two years it appears 'bands' of magnetic field move to the surface. This combines with the existing 11-year solar cycle, causing even more powerful coronal mass ejections (CMEs) and solar flares. The new solar season occurs when twisted, ring-shaped 'bands' of magnetic field rise from the solar interior and pass to the surface. This creates turbulent regions of activity on the surface, causing mega storms that pummel Earth's atmosphere can be amplified.
