The question, 'So when is Cheryl’s birthday?' was one of 25 questions set in the Singapore and Asian Schools Math Olympiad. Albert and Bernard just became friends with Cheryl, and they want to know when her birthday is. Cheryl gives them a list of 10 possible dates: May 15, May 16, May 19, June 17, June 18, July 14, July 16, August 15, August 17. To reach the answer, it is possible to work through the information both men known to rule out nine of the dates in a number of steps.

Scientists in Belgium say all sweet potatoes contain 'foreign DNA' Agrobacterium bacteria in the crop exchanges genes between species. This makes sweet potatoes a 'natural genetically modified organism' And humans have been eating it for thousands of years. Harvard-led study has mapped taste buds on a tongue for the first time. Scientists examined the different cells used to identify taste. They watched these cells capture and process molecules live. Shining a bright infrared laser on the mouse’s tongue caused different parts of it and ‘flavour molecules’ to fluoresce. This suggests tasting might ‘involve an interaction between the food taken orally and blood composition'

Ephedra foeminea is the only plant species so far that’s known to follow the lunar cycle. It waits for the full moon to 'bloom' and produces a sugary fluid to attract pollinating insects. Droplets ooze from the plant’s female organs where seeds are produced. Researchers from Stockholm University noticed the droplets at the same time of the year having conducted four years of research.

Salt card was created by Joel Paglione and Niko Zistakis in Chicago. It is designed to end the tiresome task of manually unlocking a smartphone or tablet by automatically making it come to life whenever the user is nearby. Card locks devices again as soon as a user moves out of range at a distance of 10 feet (three metres) It connects to an app on a user’s Android handset or iPhone via Bluetooth and also tells them if they have strayed too far from their wallet. The duo claim it will save people around 53 hours over a year, based on the time it takes to type a password into their phone 150 times a day.

The Optimal case was designed by Israel-based Amited. Sensors in the case monitor the phone's temperature and if it gets too hot, Optimal will cool the device using two built-in micro-fans. Optimal will be available for pre-order for Apple, Samsung, Nexus, HTC & Xperia phones on 9 April.

The company, which began as a single shop in Burton-on-Trent 25 years ago, has become Europe's largest single-price discount retailer. Total revenue over the 12-month period grew 11.8 per cent to just over £1.1 billion. Ms Scott's sister Kim Scott asked attendees of a memorial picnic to 'wear yellow' in her memory. Hundreds of women around the country hung up their wedding dresses under the hashtag #WearATouchOfYellow. New Horizons spacecraft has taken its first colour image of Pluto and its largest moon Charon. The image was taken from a distance of 71 million miles (115 million km) The spacecraft will fly by on 14 July - humanity’s first ever visit to Pluto. It will map the surface of Pluto and its moon Charon to a resolution of 25 miles (40km) This will reveal the surface features of Pluto - which may include ice.
Filmmaker Michael König from Cologne, Germany has created an amazing video showing solar activity. It was made by stitching together footage from Nasa's Solar Dynamics Observatory over five years. The movie, called Sun, was created by filmmaker Michael König from Cologne, Germany. It uses footage recorded by Nasa’s Solar Dynamics Observatory (SDO) spacecraft between 2011 and 2015. Highlights include large, bright tendrils extending outward from the sun’s surface and occasionally crashing down again.

Luis sent him an email with an idea, and Bettman said he was'simply in love' Bettman and his crew began building the dining room on the snow-covered ground at 4am, using furniture they had found on Craigslist, friends' apartments and right off the sidewalk. Luis said he had submitted the couple for a photo shoot by a random photographer he found on Craigslist. Oskar Groening, 93, is set to go on trial charged with complicity in the killing of 300,000 Jews at the Nazi extermination camp. Auschwitz survivors and relatives of those murdered there filed into court today for the trial of Groening. He was tasked with meeting the trains bringing victims there and robbing those aboard of their possessions. Between May 16 and July 11, 1944 he was on duty when 450,000 Hungarian Jews were transported there, with 300,000 being gassed just after arrival.

The Prevention of Terrorism Act - passed in Kuala Lumpur yesterday - enables authorities to detain suspected terrorists for two years without charge or trial. But it also allows for authorities to apply for unlimited extensions after those two years expire. It effectively reintroduces controversial prospect of indefinite detention without trial in Malaysia - something Prime Minister Najib Razak originally repealed in 2012. Razak's political opponents and human rights groups had urged for the bill to be withdrawn, claiming it is 'open to abuse and is a grievous blow to democracy'

A 'blob' of warm water 2,000 miles across is sitting in the Pacific Ocean. Since last June it has extended from Alaska to Mexico. It has been present since 2013 and causing fish to seek shelter elsewhere. And a new University of Washington study says it could be responsible for droughts. It could also be circulating cold and wet air to the central and eastern states of the US.

Study claims 'taxibots' could cut number of cars needed to perform same number of journeys per day by 90 per cent. Finding comes amid reports that companies such as Google and Uber are working on technology to develop driverless taxis. By plugging data into a computer model, they simulated how such self-driving, communal cabs would affect traffic. Even with only one passenger per ride, the number of cars still dropped by 77 per cent.

It was previously thought that the woolly mammoth simply died out from post-Ice Age climate change and being hunted to extinction by early man. But new evidence from Russia has found more than 23,500 mammoth bones were riddled with osteoporosis and lacking in calcium. The major mineral deficiency resulted in them breaking their limbs and spines, and left them unable to walk. In turn it meant the giant animal, which stood 10ft (three metres) high, collapsed to the ground and could not forage for food, or flee hunters.
Saudi-led coalition has destroyed air defense systems of the Houthis, a Saudi source says. Yemen has been in disarray for some time, beset by widespread poverty and insecurity.
The map above shows the average yearly counts of lightning flashes per square kilometer from 1995 to 2013. Results show that the highest amounts of lightning flashes occur in the far eastern Democratic Republic of Congo and Lake Maracaibo in northwestern Venezuela. The map was created using data from Nasa’s Tropical Rainfall Measuring Mission satellite. It shows the areas with the largest number of flashes - up to 150 per year per square kilometre - are shown in bright pink. The Democratic Republic of Congo was found to have the most over the period.
K-9 Angels charity rescued hundreds of stray dogs from being killed in Romania. They have re-homed at least 700 dogs in the UK and spayed over 2,500. Charity says 'euthanasia' of strays was legalised in September 2013. But they say state-appointed 'dog catchers' are rounding up the animals. They are then taken to holding pens where they can be 'clubbed to death' Charity says 'they are subjected to poor conditions and cruel treatment'

Chinese designers have developed a washing machine for cyclists. By changing the front wheel of the exercise bike into a washing machine drum it will spin as the user pedals. When ridden, the pedalling motion causes the drum to rotate, churning your clothes inside like a traditional washer. A generator inside the bike also creates electricity which can be stored for future use.

It is already fitted to a range of laptops and Intel's RealSense 3D camera can recognise and respond to facial expressions and hand gestures.

Miller built the hut out of fallen trees, leaves, rope and a tarp. There is no plumbing or electricity in the structure, which is about a half-hour's walk from campus. Miller has spent the last eight months studying by lantern and chasing away the occasional bear as his fellow students live comfortably in their dorm rooms.

The Planetary Society analysed the feasibility and cost of a crewed mission to orbit the Martian moon Phobos in 2033. It concluded such a plan could fit within NASA's human space exploration budget - but that politics is holding the decision back. The Phobos orbital mission would last approximately 30 months, with nine months of travel each way and 12 months in orbit. The program would then lead to a crewed landing on the Red Planet in 2039.

The Nebraska Department of Agriculture found the listeria in a sample of Jeni's ice cream it had randomly collected at a Whole Foods in Lincoln, Nebraska. The action follows a similar recall by Texas-based Blue Bell Creameries on Monday night. Blue Bell's ice cream was linked to ten listeria illnesses in four states, including three deaths, and listeria was found in several of the company's products.

St Patrick's Parish in Stephensville, Wisconsin has discontinued its 'pig rassle' tournament after 44 years. Global Conservation Group, an animal advocacy group, launched an online petition claiming the tournament was inhumane to the pigs. The group also accused the church of being in violation of Wisconsin Chapter 951, Crimes Against Animals, which outlaws cockfighting, dog fighting and any other similar fighting between animals and humans. Global Conservation Group said they consider the church's decision a victory for their 260-day campaign and consider this a huge step for animal welfare.

A Japan Railway maglev train hit 603 kilometers per hour (374 miles per hour) on an experimental track. The train covered nearly 20 football fields in the time it took you to read the last two sentences.
Researchers from the University of Patras took thermal infrared photographs of 41 volunteers’ faces, before and after drinking four glasses of wine. They then used artificial neural networks to compare the sober and drunken images pixel-by-pixel. Temperature of the forehead and nose is the best indication of a person’s drunken state and built an algorithm to recognise intoxication with 90% accuracy. Technology could be used by police to spot drink drivers and stop them starting the ignition.

Photographers captured some remarkable pictures of the Lyrid meteor shower above the UK last night. The meteor shower has been observed for the past 2,700 years and peaked overnight with between ten and 20 an hour. The cosmic show will continue on into Saturday, so it is still possible to catch a glimpse of some meteors.

Scientists at Massachusetts General Hospital and Harvard Medical School developed the device that clips onto an iPhone camera. It uses powerful cameras and tiny beads that bind to cancerous cells. When added to a tissue or blood sample, these microbeads alter the way the light is scattered by the sample. When clumped together, the microbeads produce distinctive diffraction patterns. This can be detected by a central computer and can be used in home care.

Simon and girlfriend Michelle Bird used the 39-year-old for slave labour. Police have now released CCTV footage showing the pair dragging the cases. Simon was found guilty of murder at Birmingham Crown Court today. Bird was convicted of assisting an offender and sentenced to two years.

Cavemen and women sketched an array of prehistoric beasts on the rough limestone walls of a cave in modern day France 36,000 years ago. Now experts have recreated the works of art in the cave to create the biggest replica cave in the world. The cave called the Caverne du Pont-d'Arc has been built a few miles from the original site in Vallon-Pont-D'arc in Southern France. It contains 1,000 painstakingly-reproduced drawings of 425 animals as well as around 450 bones and other features.

Scott said he immediately requested a parent-teacher conference, but Perry brought along her husband Bill, who sits on the county Board of Education. The pair showed him what he described as anti-Obama internet propaganda.

The school said that it has taken'significant adjustments to our standards' to help Rose, including reducing her workload and paring down assignments and tests.

Sonnenspeicher uses a lithium iron phosphate battery to store energy harnessed by solar panels. This energy is used throughout the day, and any excess is stored for when the sun goes down. Rather than selling this excess electricity back to the grid, homeowners can then use their stored supply for power. Sonnenspeicher is designed to be completely independent of the national power grid.

Stormy weather system known as an East Coast Low is causing gales and storm force winds. It hasn't hit NSW this strong since 2007 and is expected to be one of the longest lasting ever. The East Coast Low is particularly common in June and tends to be more frequent in autumn and winter. On Monday night 24 Sydney suburbs incurred 100mm of rainfall, with Blacktown hit hardest. An estimated 100,000 homes are without power on Tuesday morning across Sydney, the Central Coast and Hunter region.

The Shoe that Grows has adjustable points at the front, sides and the back. It can expand by five sizes by adjusting the straps at the front and back and the poppers on the toe to help it expand. Kenton Lee came up with the idea while working in Nairobi in Kenya. He said the shoe can automatically lace up, adjusting itself to the shape of your foot. Pressure sensors in the shoe tell it when your foot is in position, triggering a tiny motor in the heel that pulls the laces tight. When you want to take off the shoes, click your heels together twice and the motor releases a spring in the shoe’s tongue, loosening the laces so the footwear can be slipped off.

They build nests under rocks during mating season and sing to attract visitors. Males sing to woo females and change tune depending on their location. Researchers at the Swiss Federal Institute of Technology in Zurich say 75% of extreme hot weather and 18% of heavy precipitation is being driven by global warming. They warn that as climate change pushes global temperatures higher over the coming decades, humans will be responsible for 40% of extreme rainfall events. The rarest and most destructive events that seem to be the most responsive to human influence are the rarest and most destructive, they say.

Teller Lake in Boulder, Colorado, has been invaded by 3,000 to 4,000 goldfish. Wildlife officials say the fish started as someone dumping 'four or five' of their pets in the water two or three years ago. The animals have multiplied to over 3,000 or 4,000, it's believed. The fish are threatening to over-run the natural species in the lake, by eating up all their resources and spreading unnatural diseases.

Palaeontologists at the University of Alberta examined a pair of fossils found in Mongolia. One is a complete skeleton, while the other is missing the middle and end of its tail. They found signs of sexual dimorphism in the length and shape of blade-like bones called chevrons, which point downwards from the vertebrae near the base of the tail. They suggest that male oviraptorosaurs had broader and longer chevrons in their tails so they could shake their feather-tipped tail to woo potential mates.

The Black Book of Carmarthen is the earliest surviving medieval manuscript written solely in Welsh. It contains some of the earliest references to Arthur and Merlin. Researchers believe a 16th century owner erased centuries' worth of additional verse, doodles and marginalia which had been added to the manuscript as it changed hands throughout the years.

Scientists in The Netherlands were using the Lofar radio telescope. They found it could measure changes in lightning caused by cosmic rays. A storm can have hundreds of millions of volts over multiple kilometres. The method could provide a novel way to understand thunderclouds. University of Manchester researchers have revealed an HD dark matter map. It shows clumps of mystery particles across 0.4 per cent of the sky. The goal is to eventually map 12.5 per cent over five years. Red here shows more dark matter, and blue shows less. The map was released today at the American Physical Society in Baltimore, Maryland. It was created using data captured by the Dark Energy Camera. The map is the first in a series of maps that will allow astronomers to study how galaxies formed in the universe.

Few visitors are allowed beyond the 'No Trespassing' sign and a remote-controlled gate and into the desert and mountain environment. At the opposite end — of Texas and the competition — is the highly visible SpaceX venture, led by PayPal co-founder and electric car maker Elon Musk. Both men have seemingly unlimited resources — Bezos' wealth is estimated at nearly $35 billion, Musk's at $12 billion — and lofty aspirations: launching a new era of commercial space operations, in part by cutting costs through reusable rockets.

Swedish scientists analysed 10,000 families with children aged two to 14. 58 children were diagnosed with type 1 diabetes, many badly affected by events. They said damaging events in childhood could affect beta cells. This could raise insulin demands to cope with elevated levels of stress hormones. Other factors include viral infection, dietary habits, birth weight and early weight gain.

Researchers reviewed more than 800 school threats covered in the media during the first half of the 2014-15 academic year. About one-third of cases involved violent remarks sent anonymously via text message, social media, email or other online means. Law enforcement officers say the use of the modern technologies has made it much harder to determine if a threat is real and to find the culprit.

Maps were created by US Geological Survey cartographer Trent Hare. They include image mosaics and topographical views of the lunar landscape. Grey and white areas reveal higher peaks, while darker blues show deep craters. To the left of these craters is Oceanus Procellarum, which is Latin for 'Ocean of Storms'
Astronomers have used a telescope in New Mexico to watch a star take shape over eight years. The first image was taken with the Karl G. Jansky Very Large Array in New Mexico in 1996. The second was taken by an international team of astronomers led by the National Autonomous University of Mexico last year. The dramatic changes, in a cosmic blink of an eye, is giving an unprecedented look at how young ‘protostars’ develop into fully-fledged stars.

Unique event happened in an ancient cluster of stars at the edge of the Milky Way galaxy. When a star reaches its white dwarf stage, nearly all of the material from the star is packed inside a radius one hundredth that of the original star. Gravity at the surface of a white dwarf is over ten thousand times higher than the gravity at the surface of the Sun.

Scientists in California have described how to create artificial auroras on Earth. They said a particle accelerator could be sent 185 miles (300km) up into space. It would then fire high-energy beams back at Earth's atmosphere. The beam would then trigger different forms of lightning, including red sprites and blue jets.

He would meet and photograph women as they came in at eight in the morning for three shots of cognac before going out to walk the streets. Linguist Shigeru Miyagawa says humans developed rapidly. He says single words bear traces of syntax showing that they must be descended from an older, syntax-laden system. This is not the case with monkeys who utter isolated sounds, such as alarm calls.

The strange formation was photographed by amateur astronomer Gordon Ewen, and is a sun spot. Sun spots occur when a concentration of magnetic fields causes the surface temperature to reduce. They range in size, from just 10 miles (16km) to 100,000 miles (160,000km) wide - big enough to be seen from Earth without a telescope. Sunspots have a temperature of anywhere from 2,700 to 4,200°C (4,890 to 7,590°F) compared to 5,500°C (9,930°F) for the surrounding solar material.

Nasa scientists in California have revealed new images of the dwarf planet Ceres. They reveal new views of the two brightest spots in a crater. However, scientists are still not able to explain what they are. Dawn will begin its first science orbit around Ceres on 23 April. Several theories currently exist for what they might be, with the favoured being salt flats or ice - both reflecting sunlight.

Researchers have found traces of compounds in yarrow and camomile. They were found in plaque on teeth of 50,000-year-old Neanderthals in Spain. This suggests they may have used them to make food more palatable. Animal bones found at sites inhabited by Neanderthals are free of gnaw marks. This suggests that fat and meat had been cooked off the bones.

The car was fitted with a 3.7-litre engine developing around 240bhp, giving it a 0-60mph time of nine seconds and a top speed of 140mph. It is expected to fetch £1million at Bonhams auction house next month - more than double the £431,200 it sold for four years ago.

Jerusalem syndrome affects people visiting the holy city. It is characterised by anxiety, agitation and nervousness. Seven stages include need to be clean and performing sermons. The final stage is usually followed by a procession or march to one of the city's holy places.

The Megalithic site of Gunung Padang was discovered in 1914. It is nestled among volcanoes, banana palms and tea plantations. Dr Hilman believes the site is culturally important because it is an ancient pyramid which was built between 9,000 and 20,000 years ago. If true, it will be the oldest pyramid on Earth.

US researchers say very few of these weight loss plans have solid evidence. Only a few have shown users lose more weight than those not using them. Others produce no better results than people dieting on their own. Crucially, very few have been shown to keep the weight off permanently. But a handful - including Weight Watchers, the Atkins diet, Jenny Craig and NutriSystem - do appear to be effective, according to long-term studies.

The One-Touch-911 app was designed by researchers at MIT. It lets users call the police, fire service, report a car crash or seek medical help. Each of the four buttons on the app trigger a standard call to nearby dispatchers. If the user doesn't have signal on their network, the app lets them 'roam' onto another network to connect the call. Calls can also be routed through a Wi-Fi network. It can be used in 135 countries and is compatible with any three-digit emergency number.

Research by wildlife charity the WWF identified 11 'deforestation fronts' where 80 per cent of projected global forest losses by 2030 could occur. The areas are the Amazon, the Atlantic Forest and Gran Chaco, and the Cerrado in South America, the Choco-Darien in Central America, the Congo Basin, East Africa, eastern Australia. The fronts are home to indigenous communities that depend on forests for livelihoods and endangered species. They are being lost to expanding agriculture, including livestock farming, palm oil plantations and soy production, said the WWF.

The cremated bone was discovered during excavations in Landford, Essex. It includes approximately just over four ounces (118g) of cremated bone. It was placed into a pit with a diameter of about three feet (one metre) and backfilled with soil. Three radiocarbon dates, two from bone fragments and one from charcoal, have confirmed the remains are around 7,614 years old.

US YouTube user Elman511 cracked open an over-sized egg that was laid by one of his hens. He exclaimed: ‘The big egg has another normal egg in it!’ The instance is extremely rare, but it’s caused when the hen is in the process of forming an egg in her oviduct and another oocyte – the ovum or egg cell that becomes the yolk of the egg – is released too soon. In a counter-peristalsis contraction, a second oocyte is released by the ovary before the first egg has completely traveled through the oviduct and been laid.

Orchids have a large and irregular modified petal called the lip. It attracts insects and serves as a landing platform for them. Scientists from National Chung Hsing University in Taiwan studied the expression of genes known to be associated with petal development. They found that in mature orchid flowers, two protein complexes, called the 'L' complex and the 'SP' complex, compete to form the lip and standard petals. They were able to convert lips into petals in two orchid species.

Spanish researchers say climate change impacted human migration. Until 1.4 million years ago it was too cold to inhabit southeast Spain. But then the climate warmed to 13°C (55°F) and became more humid. This enabled hominins - our distant ancestors - to move to new regions. This allowed them to branch out from Africa into Spain, and spread across Europe.

Research on infants’ brains by Oxford University doctors overturns medical consensus. Until now doctors had assumed that the brains of very young babies are not developed enough to feel pain. New findings suggest that babies' pain thresholds are even lower than those of adults.

Researchers at Yale University have revealed subtle differences in sentence structure across the US. They have been conducting nationwide surveys using an online crowdsourcing platform asking for people's judgment on sentences. In New York, for instance, there's a tendency to use the word'so' for drama, such as 'I'm so totally over this'

Hospitalizations from car crashes dropped 7 percent between 2003 and 20010 in the 45 states with texting bans. Arizona, Texas, Montana, Missouri, and Oklahoma are the only five states in America that do not have texting at the wheel bans for all drivers. The greatest benefit was seen in states where texting bans are strictly enforced and where an officer can stop a car just on suspicion the driver breaking the law.

Duke University researchers compared their results to the most severe emissions scenarios outlined by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change. They claim these 'climate wiggles' can slow or speed the rate of warming from decade to decade, and exaggerate or offset the effects of increases in greenhouse gas concentrations. If not properly explained and accounted for, they may skew the reliability of climate models and lead to over-interpretation of short-term temperature trends.

YouTuber Dave Hax’s clever new kitcken trick lets cooks peel potatoes without using a peeler. The method starts by running the blade of a sharp knife around the middle of the potato, without letting it cut through the flesh. The method is so simple that the potatoes remain warm under their skins.

The £1.49 ($1.99) iOS app keeps a record of a user's personal radiation. This includes exposure from changes in a person's location and flights. There were at least three reports of people trying to release gopher tortoises in the ocean because they were mistaken for sea turtles. Gopher tortoises have toes, with claws on each toe and sea turtles have flippers with just one or two claws on each fore flipper. Gopher tortoises are protected by Florida law and sea turtles are on Florida's endangered species or threatened survival list.

Scientists at the University of Bristol examined a pair of fossils found in Mongolia. One is a complete skeleton, while the other is missing the middle and end of its tail. They found male and female stegosaurus had different shaped plates. This raises the possibility that the dinosaurs used its giant bony protrusions, which could reach up to 2.5 feet, to attract a mate.
St George's County Asylum in Stafford, West Midlands, opened in 1818 and once housed nearly 1,000 patients. It expanded over 350 metres in length overlooking the town of Stafford and is set to be transformed into 102 apartments. The asylum was initially large enough for 120 patients but between 1879 and 1884 two extra wings were added. Dysentery and syphilis were said to have been commonplace at the now run down asylum.

A report suggests carbon dioxide produced by burning fossil fuels could be captured and used to produce the fizz in Cola. Many nations are looking into Carbon Capture and Storage (CCS) technologies as a way to cut their greenhouse house emissions. CCS refers to the process of capturing carbon released by burning fossil fuels and storing it in porous rock layers in areas such as depleted oil and gas reservoirs. Technology has the potential to reduce the emissions of a typical coal-power plant by up to 90 per cent. But there are concerns over storing such huge amounts of carbon underground.

Researchers at the Technical University of Braunschweig, Germany, used peppermint plants in mulching and fumigation experiments. They found that plants can take up high concentrations of nicotine from contaminated soils, as well as taking in the drug from smoke. Finding may explain why some spices, herbal teas and medicinal plants have high concentrations of nicotine in them. Nicotine was frequently used as an insecticide until it was banned by the European Union in 2009 because of its toxicity.

The Kola fireball was found in the sky near the Russian-Finnish border. It had a 'disturbingly similar' path to asteroid 2014 UR116, which is due to pass by the moon in 2017. Researchers used camera footage to help recreate its trajectory. They then used a computer model to predict its trajectory. This led them to the Annama meteorite, which is an ordinary H5 chondrite - a group of space rocks with high strength that make up 31 per cent of meteorite falls.
Tamoxifen kills off cancer cells or stunts their growth by blocking the cancer-causing hormone oestrogen from reaching diseased cells. Study of 1,090 breast cancer patients found those who had been treated with tamoxifen had only half the risk of their cancer returning.

The attackers fled the scene and authorities are still searching for them.

The horseshoe-shaped glass walkway in Chongqing extends 87.5ft from the edge of a cliff. With jaw-dropping panoramic views from its observation deck, it is the longest cantilever bridge in the world. It can accommodate up to 200 visitors at once, with each one paying an admission fee of 60 Chinese yuan (approximately £6.30 or $9.60) to spend 30 minutes on the see-through floor.

The mobile mounds gather annually from April to July during what is thought to be their mating practice. Spider crabs migrate once a year in the Port Phillip Bay area in Southern Victoria, piling on top of each other to create a moving mound. The video shows the creatures crawling in an upwards direction, presumably to get higher up.

Gibbons are known for their loud, deafening songs that reverberate around forests. They produce soft call types, known as 'hoos', that are almost inaudible to the human ear. Researchers at Wisconsin University in Madison have been using computer algorithms to analyse the calls produced by the gibbons. They say the findings could shed light on the evolution of human speech.

The H5N2 bird flu virus has been found at a farm in northwest Iowa's Osceola County. Mary Cartwright was 20 when she was called up to work at Drakelow Shadow Factory. She spent two years testing metal for Bristol aircraft engines in the lab. The 91-year-old great-grandmother has now revisited the site 70 years later. Drakelow was one of 26'shadow' sites set up to produce engines and parts. It was built underground or into hillside so production could continue if the country came under fire.
The Martingale Betting Strategy is used throughout Australia on ANZAC Day. It involves doubling up if you lose, doubling your bet until your coins fall right. The game is one of Australia's longest lasting traditions. It is legal to be played on ANZAC Day across Returned Servicemen League clubs (RSL) and pubs.

Extraordinary aerial photographs taken above Whitefish Bay on eastern Lake Superior, Ontario, show some of the freighters lined up across a frozen expanse. They are carrying a variety of goods from Canadian grain to US iron and steel but are being hampered by slabs of ice as big as pick-up trucks. The ships desperately need a path cut through the lake by Canadian and US ice breakers, which have themselves been hampered by the extreme weather conditions.

Using radar measurements from Nasa's Mars Reconnaissance Orbiter, researchers have been able to identify thousands of glacier-like formations on Mars. They can see how thick the ice is on the radar images. This is because the ice has not evaporated into space, the dust must be protecting it. If the ice were unprotected, it would evaporate and become water vapour, owing to the low atmospheric pressure on Mars.

The SS City of Cairo was travelling from Bombay to England in 1942. It was torpedoed by a U-boat 480 miles south of St Helena, taking 100 tons of rupees. It was assumed that the vessel's cargo, belonging to the UK Treasury, would be lost forever. But a British-led team used pioneering techniques to track down the ship. They recovered the coins from a record depth of 17,000ft - 4,500ft deeper than the Titanic.

Money was collected from students at the University of Surrey. It was submerged in agar - a substance that allows bacteria to grow quickly. Money was monitored for three to four days and found thousands of bacteria colonies living on the sample of money. Most of the bacteria found on the coins studied was harmless. Bacillus mycoides, which is common in soil, was found on a ten pound note. It's also thought someone was gardening before handling cash.

Easter Island statues have been spotted for hundreds of years. Experts believe they have finally discovered how the Rapa Nui people placed distinctive 'hats' on top of some of the figures’ heads. They believe the hats, or 'pukao', were rolled up ramps to reach the top of the figures which measure up to 40ft (12 metres) tall. This is despite the largest pukaos measuring six-and-a-half feet (two metres) in diameter and weighing 12 tonnes (1,890 stone)

The secondary chamber beneath the supervolcano is not large enough to produce the levels of carbon dioxide. It is so large its partly-molten rock could fill the Grand Canyon 11 times over. Bill Gates says it is unrealistic to expect large numbers of people to become vegetarian. He says it will be possible to provide enough meat for the world's growing population as demand in developing countries increases.

Matilda Kahl, art director at Saatchi & Saatchi, wears the same outfit to work every day for three years. She says it came to her after a stressful morning when, with a fairly important meeting on the horizon, she began trying on a variety of outfits to no satisfaction. She wore 15 identical white silk blouses and several pairs of black trousers. For a 'personal touch' she added a custom-made leather rosette in homage to her mother, who used to love bows in her hair.

Pelvic organ prolapse occurs when tissue supporting pelvic organs weak. Complications include uncomfortable dragging or ‘full’ feeling, discomfort during sex. Up to half of women are thought to suffer to some degree, but far fewer seek help. Many who do seek help are offered just one solution: a hysterectomy.
Alex Vella, 61, has been banned from returning to Australia after the government cancelled his visa while he was overseas. The Federal Court this week ruled that Vella, who is described as a millionaire businessman, must pay all court costs. Police say he led a violent gang involved in kidnapping, extortion, drug dealing and drug running. Vella has been selling t-shirts and shirts with the slogan 'Bring Him Home' to fund his legal battle. The decision strands Vella in Malta, leaving 24 close family members in Australia.
Andrew Hennells posted a message on Facebook about his plans to rob Tesco. Hennells threatened staff 15 minutes before threatening them in King's Lynn. The 31-year-old was found with £410 in cash in a nearby pub. He admitted robbery and carrying a knife as an offence last month. Hennells was jailed for four years at Norfolk Crown Court today.

James Holmes, 27, was once a sought-after neuroscientist-in-training. But evidence shows months before the shooting he was preparing for violence. Prosecutors say Holmes was not mentally ill and knew exactly what he was doing. If the 12 jurors decide Holmes was insane at the time of the shooting, he will be committed indefinitely to a state psychiatric hospital.
Switzerland is the world's happiest nation thanks to healthy GDP figures. Top 10 on the list is dominated by European nations, particularly those in Scandinavia. Measures a country's population by factors contributing to contentment. Britons are happier now than they were two years ago, but still ranks in at a relatively lowly 21st place. U.S. is a full 10 places below Canada, ranking at 10th and fifth respectively. Unsurprisingly the world's least happy countries are places ravaged by war and extreme poverty.

Bruce Davis, 72, was convicted in the 1969 slayings of musician Gary Hinman and stuntman Donald 'Shorty' Shea. He was sentenced to life in prison in 1972 and was 30 years old at the time. Davis claimed he has turned his life around in prison, earning a doctoral degree in philosophy, becoming religious and ministering to other inmates. The parole board cited those accomplishments, along with his age and good behavior, as reasons to grant him parole in March last year.

New World Wealth study compares cities around the world. In the past decade, the percentage of multi-millionaires has grown by 71 per cent. In South America, multi-millionaires have grown 266%, Australia by 190%. Hong Kong is home to the most millionaires, followed by New York City.
Anthony Ray Hinton was convicted of two 1985 murders that occurred during robberies of fast-food restaurants near Birmingham. Prosecutors said Wednesday that their forensic experts couldn't determine if six crime scene bullets — which were the crux of the evidence against Hinton at an expected retrial — came from a gun investigators took from his home. The U.S. Supreme Court last year sent Hinton's case back for a potential new trial, which prompted a re-examination of the evidence.

The same jury that convicted Tsarnaev will hear testimony on. whether he should be sentenced to death or life in prison for. his crimes, starting next Tuesday. The sentencing phase of the trial is expected to take four weeks, followed by jury deliberations.

On April 10, after years of wrangling and a pronouncement by Giray's camp just last month, Ulukaya settled for an unknown sum.

Loeb has filed a lawsuit in a bid to prevent the Modern Family actress from destroying two cryopreserved female embryos, according to InTouch. The couple split in November 2013 and Vergara has refused to 'agree to their preservation under all circumstances' The lawsuit was first filed in August 2014 before it was refiled again on April 1 with updated information and after Loeb sought new legal representation.

Pham Quang Lanh, 28, had metal plate inserted over his skull after being struck by an iron bar on a building site. Botched operation caused his head to become swollen with a potentially deadly infection. Fearing he couldn't afford further medical treatment, he hoped headaches would subside. But when family looked at the wound they noticed a dozen maggots crawling under skin. They took him to Hanoi's Viet Duc Hospital where they removed maggots. Doctors say the infestation had actually saved Mr Lanh's life by eating diseased tissue.

The boys were enrolled at top private schools bankrolled by their mother Roxanne Dube, Canada's Consul General in Miami. The boys were recently moved to live with their mother in a gated community at the heart of the affluent Coral Way district. Marc boasted to investigators that this raid was not their first. The boys were enrolled at a $31,000-a-year private school.

Chandni Nigam, 19, spent six years battling demons which spawned from an obsession to do well at school, an inquest into her death was told. She would stay up late studying, resulting in sleep deprivation and a negative impact on her performance at school. Tragically, she had first told her parents she was feeling suicidal in 2013. She had even said she would stand in front of a fast train on a Tuesday to take her life - which is how she ultimately died.

More than 3,000 students accepted by University of Florida for fall. But after reading notices, they realized they would have to take classes online. They were in addition to 12,000 traditional freshman slots offered by university. Classes are part of new program - Pathway to Campus Enrollment (PaCE) - which started in 2015. It aims to accommodate a higher number of students at the flagship university.

Oxford scientists say a Mercury-like body struck the young Earth. The object would have been the heat source for our planet's core. The same object could have been responsible for creating the moon. It also explains where some rare-Earth elements came from.

Tuning forks are pieces of metal that make different pitched sounds when struck and made to vibrate. They are said to tighten sagging skin, eradicate dark circles, lessen the appearance of wrinkles and stimulate collagen. The treatments work on the same principle of Chinese acupuncture.

The two-storey hospital building in Zhengzhou, central China, is being rolled just eight metres a day on giant metal 'wheels' The large brick building is 1,700 square metres in size and needs more than 1,000 wheels to 'roll' it. The ambitious project is expected to be completed in the next couple of days.
